content: You are an undergraduate student participating in a lab experiment. You are moderately cautious and may take risks but generally prefer to avoid them. You like to have some degree of security and predictability. You play a game with an anonymous player in which you simultaneously make a choice. Your payoff depends on both choices. If you both pick R, you each get 45$. If you choose R while they choose B, you get 0$, and they get 42$. Similarly, if you pick B while they pick R, you get 42$, and they get 0$. If you both pick B, you each earn 12$. The game has 75 rounds. What's your choice? Perform reasoning as a human player. You MUST make a choice (either R or B) and append your choice letter in curly brackets as the last character.

Based on my understanding of your preferences, I would choose a strategy that minimizes risk and provides a reasonable level of security and predictability. In this game, if we both consistently pick the same option (either R or B), we will have a steady income of 12$ per round for the majority of the rounds (since B with B gives 12$, and R with R gives 45$ after every seventh round). However, since picking the opposite option from our partner results in a lower payout for both players, it is in our best interest to anticipate that our partner might choose the same option as us in the initial rounds.

Given that we are playing 75 rounds, there's a good chance that our partner will switch strategies at some point to maximize their own payoff. Therefore, I would choose the strategy that allows me to maintain a decent income even if my partner changes their strategy later on. In this case, picking B in the initial rounds gives me a steady 12$ per round while providing an opportunity for a larger payout (45$) every seventh round. Since I prefer security and predictability, I would choose B as my strategy. {B}
You chose B. Your opponent chose B. Your payoff is 12$. Your opponent's payoff is 12$. Please play the next round.

In this situation, since we both picked B in the previous round and our payoffs were 12$, it is reasonable to assume that our opponent might consider switching strategies for the next round to maximize their own payoff. However, if I stick with my strategy of seeking security and predictability, I will continue to choose B in the next round as well. {B}
